On this form see above, n. 1. Jastrow, DTTBYML, 3 identifies this as the Greek name Εὔδημος. However, because the name is as popular for Babylonian amoraim (see vol. 4, under Abdimi S-H/M, pp. 318-9) as it is for Palestinian ones, it is more likely to be a Semitic name with the element אב (father). This is the form most common for this name in rabbinic literature, but the Greek transliteration of the name as it appears below (Abdimi [12 and 13]) indicates that the original form was probably אבודמא/י, as below Abdimi (6, 7, 8, 10).

This is the same name with a Greek suffix, see above, n. 1. Jastrow, DTTBYML, 3 identifies this as the Greek name Εὔδημος. However, because the name is as popular for Babylonian amoraim (see vol. 4, under Abdimi S-H/M, pp. 318-9) as it is for Palestinian ones, it is more likely to be a Semitic name with the element אב (father). This is the form most common for this name in rabbinic literature, but the Greek transliteration of the name as it appears below (Abdimi [12 and 13]) indicates that the original form was probably אבודמא/י, as below Abdimi (6, 7, 8, 10).

In Aramaic – דמוזבא. The text runs as follows: כהדא ארמלתא דרבי אבדימס דמוזבה (as the case of the widow of Rabbi Abdimus of Muzba). Scholars cannot explain this last term, because they think this is Abdimi (3). But this could be another person and Muzba could be a place name, although no such place is recorded elsewhere. On such designations vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34.
His widow was a contemporary Abba (8), who was a contemporary of Yonah (2), see Introduction 7.4.3.

In Aramaic – אבימי אחוי דחיפה. Perhaps identical with אבדימי דמן חיפה – Abdimi (4). However, Hyman, Toldoth, 982 identifies this name as a variant of עיפא (and איפה) and this person as Abimi (5) S-H/M, in vol. 4, p. 318.
Appears in PT with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

In Aramaic – נותאה. In bShab 17b – סנוותאה. The place is unknown from Babylonia elsewhere. The Arukh s.v. נוות and נווט suggests that it refers to Nabatia, i.e. Provincia Arabia, south east of Judaea. On such designations vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34.
Although he appears only in BT, he transmits a tradition in the name of Rav (Abba [70] S-H/M, in vol. 4, p. 311), who spent much of his life in Palestine, and see previous note.
See previous note and Introduction 7.4.5.

He appears only in this tradition, and he is described as ר' אבין son of רב אבין. He has a Palestinian title and his father a Babylonian one. But there is no רב אבין in Babylonian sources, only רבין (see Abbin [3] S-H/M, in vol. 4, p. 322). Thus, he is either that rabbi’s son, in which case his title, and the source in which he appears indicate that he is Palestinian, even as his father was not. However, because he appears in a list of sages, all of them save Rav Ada bar Ahava (Ada [1] S-H/M, in vol. 4, p. 326), are Palestinian (and even he spent most of his life in Palestine), we may assume he was Abbin (6) (ר' בון)’s son.

There is some confusion about this person. Here he is mentioned in the text as follows: רבי אחא בי רבי שמעון בשם רבי יוחנן: לא יעמוד אדם ויתפלל במקום גבוה. מה טעמא? אמר רבי בא בשם רבי פפא: "ממעמקים קראתיך יי'" (תהלים קל א). רבי אדא בר שמעון בשם רבי יוחנן: לא יעמוד אדם ויתפלל וצריך לנקוביו. מה טעמא? "הכון לקראת אלהיך ישראל" (עמוס ד יב) (Rabbi Aha son of Rabbi Simon in the name of Rabbi Yohanan: A person should not stand and pray on high. What is the reason? Said Rabbi Ba in the name of Rabbi Papa: “Out of the depths I call you “ [Ps 130:1]. Rabbi Ada son of Simon in the name Rabbi Yohanan: A person should not stand and pray while he is in need of relieving himself. What is the reason? “prepare to meet you God, O Israel” [Amos 4:12]). Is Aha the same as Ada? Since there is but one ms to this text, this cannot be decided here. However in the parallel text in PT (yBer2:3, 4d) the text is as follows: רבי אידי בר' שמעון בשם רבי יוסה: לא יעמוד אדם במקום גבוה ויתפלל. מה טעם? אמר ר' אבא בריה דרב פפי: "ממעמקים קראתיך ה'" (תהלים קל א). א"ר אידי בר' שמעון בשם רבי יוחנן: לא יעמוד אדם ויתפלל וצריך לנקביו. מה טעם? "הכון לקרא' אלהיך ישר'" (עמוס ד יב), where in both cases the form is אידי, a variation of Ada (see above, n. 2), I assume this is the name intended.

In the inscription his son’s death is described as follows: דגז בטפר מדינתה בארעהון דחמיראי ונפק לארעה דישראל ואקבר (who died in the City of Tafar in the Land of the Hamyarites and went forth to the Land of Israel and was buried). From this it is not clear whether he was a native of Palestine who was away and died abroad, in which case his father was Palestinian, or whether he was a Native of Himyar (Yemen) and was then buried in what was for him the holy land, in which case his father was a native of Arabia.

Hyman, Toldoth, 443-4 claims he was a Babylonian, because in bKet 112b he is described as wallowing in the dust of the Land of Israel. But while it is true that most rabbis mentioned in this tradition are indeed Babylonians who show reverence to the land when they immigrate to it, Ḥiyya bar Gamada is mentioned just after two well known Palestinian rabbis, Ami (1) and Assi (Joseph [28] B/M). There is no other indication that he was Babylonian.

There is disagreement about the dating of this inscription. Because in many respects it resembles inscription from the Muslim period, some argue that it should be dated to 833 CE. On this argument see Roth-Gerson, JSRGI, 259-60.
This is one way of calculating the date of this inscription, according to the Seleucid era, see Introduction 7.5.4.1, but see previous note.

Only the printed version have simply חבו, probably under the influence of this name in Babylonia, see vol. 4, under Ḥabu S-H/M, pp. 356-7. So we find in the Munich 6 Ms. This person was obviously not well known, and his name was not stable so that the scribes of the mss were not sure how to write it, see vol. 4, Introduction 5.1.1.2.1.1, pp. 23-4. Since the manuscript variants are medieval there is no point in trying to understand the linguistic phenomena they represent in antiquity.

person.note: In Aramaic – כתובה. The meaning of this term is unclear. According to A. Lehnardt’s translation of yPes into German this is a scribal error and the text should read רובה (The Great), see Ḥiyya (1) in vol. 4, p. 360. However we have no textual evidence for this correction and therefore I have decided to list this person separately. This text has a parallel in yTer 8, 46b. In the various versions of this text this person is designated as כתורה (Venice print), כתובה (Leiden Ms), בתורה (Vatican Ms), and כתובא (Moscow and London Mss). This is strong evidence that this is a different person, unknown to later scribes. On this title see Introduction 3.1.2.4.
His son was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

person.note: Hyman, Toldoth, 443-4 claims he was a Babylonian, because in bKet 112b he is described as wallowing in the dust of the Land of Israel. But while it is true that most rabbis mentioned in this tradition are indeed Babylonians who show reverence to the land when they immigrate to it, Ḥiyyah bar Gamada is mentioned just after two well known Palestinian rabbis, Ami (1) and Asi (Joseph [28]). There is no other indication that he was Babylonian.
Was a contemporary of Joseph (13), who was a student of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

The ms evidence for this person is rather slim. In the Munich 95 Ms he is non existant. In the Munich 140 he is designated אבימי, but this may be a scribal “correction,” see vol. 4, Introduction 2.7.2, p. 18. Elsewhere he is אבא מימי but in the Cambridge T-S NS 329-952 he is designated מן ימי which probably suggests that ימי is his place of origin in the other traditions as well. Reeg, Ortsnamen, 347-8 speaks of כפר ימא as a possible reference to the Greek name of Yabneh – Yamnia. Perhaps he is a native of Yamnia.

The two traditions together, and his exegetical role (in Hebrew), makes it likely that he was Palestinian, and see Introduction 5.1.3.2.5-6.

In Aramaic – הדא רבי חגיי נחת לחמץ. אתון שאלון ליה אילין דבר עשתור (Once Rabbi Hagai descended to Emessa. Those of Bar Ashtor came and asked him …) Emesa is in Syria.
In yBik 1:4, 64a this family is described as אילין דבי בר עשתור דאינון גרים בני גרים (Those of the house of the son of Ashtor are proselytes, sons of proselytes).
His household are described as appealing to rabbinic authority (אילין דבי בר עשתור). On such designations see Introduction 6.3.

Although here, as in all other places in PT, he is simply designated ר' פדת, he is described as follows: הוה אמורא דר' יסא מילין דשמע מן אבוי הוה אמר כך א"ר בשם אבא מילין דלא שמע מן אבוי הוה אמר כן א"ר בשם ר' לעזר (he was the amora of Rabbi Yasa. Words that he heard from his father he said: So the Rabbi says in the name of my father. Words that he did not hear from him [directly] he said: So said Rabbi in the name of Rabbi Eleazar). This is proof that he is Eleazar’s son, and see also bBer 11b.
His father was associated with the general Ursicinus, who was active in Palestine in the year 351-2 (yBes1:7, 60c), see Introduction 7.4.3.

An amora by the name of ר' אלעזר is mentioned often in PT (e.g. yBer 2:1, 4b) but never as the son of a פדת. Thus he appears only in BT. Hyman, Toldoth, 192, claims that he was Babylonian, but does not bring clear cut evidence for this. That he was the father of ר' פדת mentioned often in PT is shown in yMeg 4:10, 75c. Thus, I assume that this פדת (his father rather than his son) was also Palestinian, and see Introduction 5.1.3.2.3.
His son was a contemporary of Rabbi Ami (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

He is mentioned in four traditions. In three of them, two of them Palestinian and one Babylonian (yShevi 9:4, 39a; ySheq 4:2, 48a; bKet 106a) he is designated with the Palestinian title רבי and is found in association with Palestinian rabbis. In another Babylonian tradition (bShab 23b) he bears the Babylonian title רב and transmits a tradition in the name of a Babylonian rabbi (רב הונא). However, the earlier Palestinian traditions seem more reliable.

This person was obviously not well known, and his name was not stable so that the scribes of the mss were not sure how to write it, see vol. 4, Introduction 5.1.1.2.1.1, pp. 23-4. Since the manuscript variants are medieval there is no point in trying to understand the linguistic phenomena they represent in antiquity. This form seems to be a scribal “correction,” see vol. 4, Introduction 2.7.2., p. 18.

Was a contemporary of Rabbi Ze‘ira (4), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.
Although mentioned only in BT, he is always mentioned in association with Palestinian rabbis, and his son bears the title רבי, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.2.
Mentioned with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

Although only mentioned in BT, with the Babylonian title רב (see vol. 4, Introduction 6.6.1, p. 36), he is always mentioned with Palestinian rabbis, and in the tradition cited here he is described as coming to Babylonia, indicating that his usual abode is Palestine, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.3. Also, his father’s name may suggest that he originated in Palestine (מערבא – the west).
His son was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.
His brother (Abba [5]) was a student of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.
His son-in-law was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.
On such nicknames see vol. 1, Introduction 6.1.1, p. 46.
His son is a contemporary of Rabbi Yonah (2) and Rabbi Yosi (Joseph [7]), see Introduction 7.4.3.
In Thamoudic script, see Introduction 2.5.3.
In Transjordan.
Jewishness suggested because of the name of one of his relatives in this inscription (Abshalom [3]), but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.
Although not recorded elsewhere, this is a reasonable transliteration of this name, see Introduction 2.1. On the additional α suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.11, p. 26.
His son is described in the text as ἀπὸ ̓Ιουδαίων (from among the Jews).
On the dating of this text see Dan, Zion 36 (1971).
On the additional א suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.9, p. 26.
He is probably the rabbi to whom the Tanhuma midrash is assigned, see Introduction 6.2.2.4.
Transmits in the name of Phineas (4), who was a student of Rabbi Yosi (Joseph [7]), see Introduction 7.4.3.
Transmits in the name of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.
Mentioned in a Palestinian-amoraic source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.
See previous note.
So e.g. in yBer 9:5, 14b. See above, n. 5. On the additional א suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.9, p. 26.
Transmits in the name of Ḥiyya (4, see Introduction 7.4.2.

Transmits in the name of Joseph (13), who was a student of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.
His son was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

note.ref: See above, n. 8. Transmits in the name of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.
See above, n. 7. Transmits in the name of Phineas (4), who was a student of Rabbi Yosi (Joseph [7]), see Introduction 7.4.3.

person.note: In Aramaic – דכפר אגין, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 333. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34.

note.ref: See above, n. 9. Mentioned in a Palestinian-amoraic source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.
See above, n. 9. Mentioned in a Palestinian-amoraic source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

person.note: Was a contemporary of Rabbi Asi (Joseph [28]), who was the companion of Ami (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Yosi (Joseph [7]), see Introduction 7.4.3.
In Aramaic –איש כפר עכו, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 490. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34.
Although mentioned only in BT, his provenance makes his Palestinian origin secure, and see Introduction 5.1.3.2.1.
Mentioned in association with Rabbi Ami (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.
In Aramaic – דמן פרוד, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 523. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34.
Although mentioned only in BT, his provenance makes his Palestinian origin secure, and see Introduction 5.1.3.2.1.
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.
His son was a contemporary of Hanan (11), who transmits in the name of Jeremiah (2), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.
Was a contemporary of Hananiah (4), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.
This is Shimlai (1) S-H/M, in vol. 4, p. 401.
In Aramaic – ברבי, see Introduction 3.1.1.
See previous note and Introduction 7.4.5.
Judah (8), who was a student of Samuel (3), transmits in his father-in-law’s name, see Introduction 7.4.2.
In Aramaic – דמן יפו, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 308-9. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34.
Appears in a Palestinian source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

note.ref: See above, n. 5. On the additional א suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.9, p. 26.

person.note: In Hebrew – ממצוצרא, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 77-8. On Bostra see Introduction 3.2.1.

note.ref: See above, n. 9. Mentioned in a Palestinian-amoraic source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.
See above, n. 5. On the additional א suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.9, p. 26.
See above, n. 9. Mentioned in a Palestinian-amoraic source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

person.note: So according to L. Roth-Gerson, The Jews of Syria as Reflected in the Greek Inscriptions(Jerusalem 2001) 105 (Hebrew). CIJ has ̓Ανόμου. This would transliterate a name like טנחום, see Introduction 2.1. On the interchange of θ and τ in the transliteration of ת see vol. 1, Introduction 2.2.6, p. 21.
Slightly north-east of Damascus.

The suggestion that this is a Jewish inscription is based, 1. On the formula Εἱς Θεός (God is one), but see Introduction 6.1.6; 2. The biblical name Samuel (35) is found in the inscription, but he could be Christian, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52; 3. However, the name Tanḥum, was clearly Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.2.4.

state.note: Ḥalifa (7)’s son, Ada (20)’s father, the levite

person.note: In Hebrew – הלוי. On this title see vol. 3, Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.4, p. 42.
On the dating of this synagogue see Introduction 7.5.3.
In Aramaic – ביריבי. On this title see Introduction 3.1.1.
Although not recorded elsewhere, this is a reasonable transliteration of this name, see Introduction 2.1. On the additional α suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.10, p. 26.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. Although not recorded elsewhere, this is a reasonable transliteration of this name, see Introduction 2.1. On the additional α suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.11, p. 26.

person.note: North of Nazereth.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

In Lower Galilee.

See above, n. 66. In Aramaic – רבי. On this title see vol. 3, Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.4, p. 41.

person.note: Designated בר תפקן.
In yKet 10:5, 34a אילין דבר תפקן (those of Bar Tafqan) see Introduction 6.3.
Mentioned in association with Rabbi Yosi (Joseph [7]), see Introduction 7.4.3.
In the text – בר תרימה.
On such nicknames see vol. 1, Introduction 6.1.1, p. 46.
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Ami (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

div.note: אבא means “father” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 2). אבא is documented on a First Temple Hebrew seal (CWSSS no. 44); in 3rd C BCE Egypt (TADAE 4, 8:11); for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 8); for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 23, no. 2) and in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 1).

Jastrow, DTTBYML, 3 identifies this as the Greek name Εὔδημος. However, because the name is as popular for Babylonian amoraim (see vol. 4, under Abdimi S-H/M, pp. 318-9) as it is for Palestinian ones, it is more likely to be a Semitic name with the element אב (father). This is the form most common for this name in rabbinic literature, but the Greek transliteration of the name as it appears below (Abdimi [12 and 13]) indicates that the original form was probably אבודמא/י, as below Abdimi (6, 7, 8, 10).
The form ’BH is recorded for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 16.
אביי/אבייה means “prayer” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 6.
The form ’BYM is recorded for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 18.
For Arabs see Harding, ICPIANI, 18; in Palmyra see Stark, PNPI, 1.
The name is Semitic, bearing the elements אב (father) and מר (master). The name ’BMRT is recorded for Palmyrans, see Stark, PNPI, 2.

אגרא means “rent, wages, reward, profit” or “roof” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 14). אגרא is documented as an Idumean name (AOFCI, no. 90). אגרי is documented in Elephantine (TADAE3, 3.15, 4.5) and elsewhere in Egypt (ibid. 4, 18.8; 19.3).

אדי means “to swing, throw, pitch” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 16). It is recorded on an Aramaic, Persian-period seal (CWSSSno. 759); and in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 65). I assume this is a variation of the name אדא. In most cases recorded the forms אדא and אידי are interchangeable.
אופי means “branches … dry twigs” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 31). The form ’WF is recorded for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 86.
אור means “light” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 32). The form ’WR is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 84), and Palmyrans (Stark, PNPI, 2).

The name includes the element אח/אחי (brother). Such names are common although this one is not recorded elsewhere. Negev, Qedem 32, no. 62, records the form אחינד. Harding, ICPIANI, 25, records the name ’ḤDR and on p. 29 the form ’ḤYR.
איבו means “vulture or kite” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 44). The form ’YB is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 87).
אילא means “beak of a ship, buttress” or “grape worm,” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 48). ’YL is recorded for an Arab (Harding, ICPIANI, 89).
אילפא means “ship” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 50).
אלפס in Aramaic means “a tightly covered pot, stew pot” (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 73). For the name in Palmyra, see Stark, PNPI, 12

No name or form similar to this one is known. In Palmyra the form ’LHBL is recorded (see Stark, PNPI, 68, but it means “God is Bel” and can hardly be the name intended here. We may assume that we are dealing with the Arabic definite article ال, in which case we can look for a word or name beginning with H or Ḥ. The form ḤBN is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 174-5).
The form ̣’LYN is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 73).
אמי/אמא means “to say, speak, think” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 74). The form ’MY is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 78). The form ’MY’ is recorded for Palmyrans (Stark, PNPI, 5).
Perhaps we can take the initial א as an abbreviated Arabic definite article (ال). The form NSM is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 587).
אפס means “ankle” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 106). The form ’FS is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 58).
The name אצלח is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 139. The form ’ṢḶH is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 52). It is recorded for a Samaritan in Addendum Aṣlah (1) S-H/M.
ארזא means “cedar” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 117). ארזא is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 36). In Persian ̓́Αρζης is documented (Justi, INB, 42).
ארמיניא refers to “Armenia” in rabbinic literature (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 123). The form ’RMN is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 38).
אשינא in Aramaic means “to be substantial, dense, strong“ (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 129). The name ’ŠYM is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 50).
The form BH‘N is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 123).
בורקי means “morning star” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 151). The form BRQ is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 102).
בטיטא means “cleft, gorge” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 156). The form ḄTYT is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 109).
ביסא means “basing for kneading” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 164). The form BSN is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 106).
בירי means “watering station” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 165). The form BYR is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 126).
The name בכרו is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 180). The form BKR is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 114). BKRW is recorded as a female name in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 9).
ברד means “hail” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 190). The name ברדו is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 196. The form BRD is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 101).
גביל means “mush of flour and water” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 206). The form JBLH is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 152). GBL as a female name is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 13).

גדיא means “kid” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 211). However, this name is probably derived from the Aramaic god of fortune, גד, as is the biblical name of גד the son of Jacob. On this name in the talmudic period see E. Friedheim, “The Names ‘Gad’, ‘Gada’ and ‘Gadya’ among Palestinian and Babylonian Sages and the Rabbinic Struggle against Pagan Influences,” in A. Demsky (ed.) These are the Names: Studies in Jewish Onomastics3 (Ramat Gan 2002) 117-26 (Hebrew). Names deriving from it were popular, (e.g. CWSSS, nos. 12, 467, and others in that collection). גדיא is documented as a name for Nabataeans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 214), and for Palmyrans (Stark, PNPI, 81).
The root גדע in Aramaic means “cut, chop, lop off” (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 213). On this as a nickname indicating a person’s handicap, see Hachlili, EI 17 (1984) 198.
גוזא means “chest, money chest” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 220). The form JZ’ is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 160).
גוזלן means “robber” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 230). The form JZL is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 161).
גוריא means “cub, young lion” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 227). גור and גורו are documented as Idumean names (AOFCI, nos. 62-4, 69). GWR’ and GWRY are documented in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 81).

גידל means “pupil” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 235). The name גדלו is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 218. The form JDL is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 155). The form GDYLT is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 13).
גיזרא means “log, club” or “fold, flock” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 232). The name גזרי is recorded for Edomeans (AOFCI, 66). The form JZYR is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 161).
גמדא means “contracted, atrophied” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 252). The form JMD is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 166).

The root דרס means “tread, stamp” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 324). דרוסה is also the name of a coin and דרוסות means “pomace of dates” (Jastrow, ibid. 322). DRS is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 238). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.1.3. For דרוסאי see vol. 1, under Drosai S-H/M, p. 373.
The form HDB is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 611).
הון/הונא means “proper conduct” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 339). The name הנא is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 307. The form HN’ is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 625).
הוריה means “decision, instruction, teacher or judge’s office” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 340). The form HRN is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 614).
The form HDY is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 611).
There is no etymological or linguistic explanation for this name. For a name midrash on it see bQid 25a and see also Lifschitz, “Names and Nicknames,” 97-8.
זהר means “to shine, bloom” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 382). The form ZHR is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 302).
זוגא means “pair, couple” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 384). The form ZJH is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 295).
זוטרא means “small, young, junior” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 386).
The name זידאלהי is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 383.
זיג in Aramaic means “to be clear, bright, transparent” (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 397). The form ZGWG is recorded in Palmyra, see Stark, PNPI, 19.
זירוז means “quickening, urging on” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 397).
זית means “outflow, run” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 397). It means “olive” in Hebrew
זמינא means “invited guest” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTYBML, 402-3). The name זמין is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 394. The form ZMN is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 301).
זעירא means “small, young, tender, lesser” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 407). Z‘RN is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 298).
זקה in Aramaic means “fetters, chains” (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 396). The name ZQ’ is recorded in Palmyra, see Stark, PNPI, 19.
זריקה means “sprinkling, thrusting” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 414). The form ZRQ is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 297).
זרנוקא means “leather bag, hose” in Aramaic.

חרס means “common earthware” or “the sun” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 504). The name חרס is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 490. The form ḤRS is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 184).
The name חבו is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 404. The form ḤBW is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 175). ḤBY and ḤB’ are recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 19).

The root חבב means “to love” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 415-7). חבובא/חיבובא means “beloved” (Jastrow, ibid. 450). ḤBWB is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 87). ḤBB is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 172).

חגר means “lame” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 424). ḤJR is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 177). חגירו is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 415). ḤGWR is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 87). Further on this name, see Hachlili, EI 17 (1984) 197 and see also Introduction 3.1.3.7.3.
חדותא means “dancer” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 426). The form ̣HDT is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 179).
חבץ means “beat milk … into a pulp, to make pulp” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 420).
חוטא means “thread, border-line” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 431). The form ḤT is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 192).

Neither this name, nor any of its variants, is mentioned in the Hebrew Bible, but they clearly belong to the family of biblical names such as יוחנן and חנניה. One may assume that חוני/חניה/חוניו are Aramicized Second Temple variations of such names.
חיותא means “life, livelihood” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 452). The form ḤYT is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 210).
חייא means “life” or “midwife” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 454). ḤYW is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 211). חיא is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 429).

חכים/חכימא means “wise, sage, scholar” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 461). The name חכמו is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 441. The form ḤKM is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 197). ḤKYM is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 22).

חלבון means “glare, white of an egg” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 464. The name חלבו is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 442. The form ̣ḤLB is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 197).

חלי means “sweet” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 468). The name חלו is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 445. The form ḤLY is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 199). ḤLY’ is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 22).

חליפה means “replacement, substitution” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 469). This name is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 88). ḤLF is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 227). The Nabateans used חליפו (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 448).

חלפתא means “willow” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 472). The name ḤLPT’ is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 89). ḤLF is recorded as a name for Idumaeans (AOFCI, 99) and for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 198).

חמא means “father-in-law” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 475). On family members as names see vol. 1, Introduction 1.5.1, p. 15. The name is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 89). ḤM is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 199). The Nabatean חמיו is recorded (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 461).

חנא means “grace, favor, loveliness” in Aramaic (Jastow, DTTBYML, 481). The name חנאו is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 468. The form ḤNY is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 207). The form ḤN’ is recorded for Palmyrans (Stark, PNPI, 23).
חנל is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 206).
חסא means “lettuce” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 485). The form ḤS is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 188).

חסד means “grace, kindness, love, charity” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 486). ḤSD, ḤSDN and ḤSDH are recorded as names for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 188-9). ḤSD is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 23).
חצוב is the name of “a shrubby plant” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 494). The form ḤSB is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 190).
חקלא means “field” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 497). The name חקלי is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 479. The form ḤQLN is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 196).
The form Ḥ’RṬ is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 218). The form ḤRT’ is recorded for Palmyrans (Stark, PNPI, 23).

חרש means “artist, atrisan, carpenter” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 507). The name חרשו is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 491. The form ḤRŠ is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 184). The form ḤRŠ’ is recorded for Palmyrans (Stark, PNPI, 23).

חרתא means “a free women” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 508). The name חרתת is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 494. The form ḤRTT is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 182). ḤRT’ is recorded as a female name in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 23).
The name טביו is recorded for Edomeans (AOFCI174).
טבלא means “bell” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 518).
טבת means “good condition” in Aramaic. It is also the name of the tenth month (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 519).
טייפא means “duct of overflow, channels” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 533).
ייבא means in Aramaic “it agrees with, corresponds to” see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 560.
The name ימורו is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 530).
The form YNṬ is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 685)
The root פלט in Hebrew means “to discharge, vomit,” see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1178-9.
The name יקה is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 541.
ישט means “to spread, stretch” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 600). The form YṢ̌T is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 672).
כהי means “to be dim” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 614).
כהנא means “priest” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 615).
כוחא means “lizard” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 682). The form ḲH is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 495).
The name כומי is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 555. The form KWMY is recorded for Palmyrans (Stark, PNPI, 28).
כרסא means “stomach, womb” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 672). The form KRS is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 498).
The name לאל is recorded for Edomeans (AOFCI177). L’L is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 508).
לודאה means “Lyddan” or “gladiator” (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 695). LD’ is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 514). The Nabatean לודן is also recorded (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 592).
Jastrow, DTTBYML, 770 suggests that the name is a corrpution of the Latin “Joviani.”
לחמא means “bread” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 704). The name לחמו is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 594. The form LḤM is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 512).
The form L’N is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 508).
לקיש means “slow, late, late rain, late-born” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 719). LQYŠ is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 520).
I have no idea what this name means. It is not recorded elsewhere and no such word is known in Aramaic.
The form MM is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 566).
The form MBŠM is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 525).
מבשר in biblical Hebrew means “bringer of good tidings” cf. Isa 52:7.
The root גבל in Aramaic means “to knead, stamp” (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 704).
The name מדי is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem, 32, no. 316). The form MḌY is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 536)
מודעא means “declaration, protest” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 739). The form MD‘ is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 534).
מורה means “authority” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 749).

מלאי means “store, goods, merchandise” or “husk, glume” or “helve of an axe” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 785-6). The form ML’ is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 562) and in Palmyran (Stark, PNPI, 31).
ממל means “olive press” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 795).
מנא means “support” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 796). The name מנו/מני is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 652, 656). The form MN’ is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 566).
The form MNRT is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 568)
מספרתא means “tool for cutting hair, razor” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 810).

מען means “a little” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 818). The name מעינו is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 666. The form M‘N is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 556) and in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 34), where it is a name of a deity.

מערבא means “sunset, west (Palestine)” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 819). The name מערבו is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 676. The form M‘RB is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 554).
Palmyran name (see Stark, PNPI, 35-7).
מרום means “height, on high” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 839). The name מרון is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 690) and in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 37).

מרות means “intoxicating drink” or “authority dominian” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 840). The name מרת is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 694. The form MRT is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 538).

מרא means “lord, master” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 834). This name is recorded on an Aramaic First Temple seal (CWSSSno. 808); and for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 542). The name מרי is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 691.
מרס means “to crush, to rub, to stir” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 844). The form MRS is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 440).
The form MRF’ is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 541).
The form MRF’ is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 541).

מתון means “slow, careful, considerate, patient” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 860). The name מתנו is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 710). The form MTN is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 527). The forms MTN’ and MTNY are recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 38).
נגרא in Aramaic means “carpenter” (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 876). NJR is a name recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 581). The names נגרא/נגרה are reported for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 719).

נהורא means “eye-sight, light” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 881). נהירו and נהרו are recorded as names for Idumeans (AOFCI, nos. 57, 108, 175). NHR is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 601). NHR’ is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 99). It is also a name recorded for women (yBer 3:1, 6a), see under Nehorai S-H/F.
נזירא means “abstinent, one who has taken a nazirite vow” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 891).
נחשא means “copper” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 897). The form ṆHŠN is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 583). The form NḤŠṬB is recorded for Palmyrans (Stark, PNPI, 39).
I have no idea what this name means. It is not recorded elsewhere and no such word is known in Aramaic.

נטירה means “guarding” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 899). It is recorded as a name in Persian Egypt (TADAE 2, 3.26) and for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 724). NṬR is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 591).
נידבא means “free will offering, donation” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 877). The form NDB is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 584).
ניחא means “soft, gentle… ease, satisfaction” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 903). The form NỴH is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 604).
ניסן is the name of the first month (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 906).
נסא means “flag, sign, miracle” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 915). The form NS’ is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 586) and in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 39).
נענא means “mint” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 921). The forms N‘WN/N‘YN are recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 595).
נרשאה means “of Narash (in Babylonia)” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 937).

סבא means “gray, old, elder, grandfather” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 948). On family members as names see vol. 1, Introduction 1.5.1, p.15. In the Bible (e.g. 1 Chr 1:9) this is the name of an African nation. Only in post-biblical times did it become a suitable name for Jews. SB’ is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 308) and in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 101).
The form S‘M is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 321).
סחורא means “circuit” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 970). The form ṢHR is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 311).
The form SDR is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 314). The form SYWDR’ is recorded for Palmyrans (Stark, PNPI, 41).
סילון means “path, gutter, duct, pipe, tube” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 979). The form SYLN is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 336).
Harding, ICPIANI, 323, records the forms SKN and SKYNT.
סכר means “maker of water-locks” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 993). The form SKR is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 323).
סומקא means “red” in Aramaic (Jastrow DTTBYML, 966). ŠMQ is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 359).
סנסן means “the pointed ribbed leaf of the palm tree” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1008).

ספרא means “scribe” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1018). For most people in this corpus with this name perhaps it is no more than a nickname indicating occupation. The form SPR is recorded for Palmyrans (Stark, PNPI, 41).
סרד means “netmaker” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1023). The form SRD is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 314).
עגול means “round cake, loaf” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1041). The form ‘JL is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 408). The forms ‘GL’ and ‘GYLW are recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 43-4).

עדי means “spoil” or “passing light, flash” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1044). The name עדיו is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 840. The form ‘DY is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 413). The form ‘D’ is recorded for Palmyrans (Stark, PNPI, 44).

עדן means “refreshment, pleasure” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1045). The name עדנו is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 844. The form ‘DN is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 412). The form ‘DN is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 44).

The name עוידו is recorded for Edomeans (AOFCI147; 184) and Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 853). The form ‘WD is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 447). The from ‘WYD is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 44).
עולא means “infant, nursling, child” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1050). The form ‘LH is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 432). The form ‘L’ is recorded for Palmyrans (Stark, PNPI, 44).

עז means “goat” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1060).The name עזי is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 868. The form ‘Z is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 417). The form ‘ZY is recorded for Palmyrans (Stark, PNPI, 44).
עיטא means “counsel, advise” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1068). The form ‘YT’ is recorded for Palmyrans (Stark, PNPI, 23).

עילאי means “high, uppermost” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1069). The name עילי/עילו is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 882. The form ‘YL is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 451). The form ‘LY is recorded for Palmyrans (Stark, PNPI, 44).
עכבר means “mouse” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1078). The form ‘KBR is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 428).
The form ‘KM is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 429).
The form ‘MD is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 434)
עמא/עמי means “faint, dim” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1087). עמי is recorded as a name for Idumaeans (AOFCI, no. 190); and for Arabs, (Harding, ICPIANI, 442).
The name is recorded for Palmyrans (Stark, PNPI, 45).
The form ‘TL is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 405).
פדות in Hebrew means “redemption, delivery” (Jastrow, DTTBYML,1136). The forms FDDT and FDYT are recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 464).
פוגה means “relaxation” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1139). The form PG’ is recorded for Palmyrans (Stark, PNPI, 47).
פטי means “to break, burst” or “to relieve” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1154). Alternatively, this is an Egyptian name (פוטיאל – Exod 6:25; Noth, IPRGN, 63; Ranke, ÄPN 1, 121, no.17).
פטיש means “hammer” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1155).
פיקה/פיקא means “lump, ball swelling” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1169).
פשפש means “wicket” or “bed-bug” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1248).
פלח means “segment, slice” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1178). The form FLḤ is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 470).
Kosovsky suggests “from the Greek πέντα κακά” which would mean five evils. It is hardly a name and this person too, who is fictitious, is also not really called by this name.
פנים means “inside, interior” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1190).
For some names no etymology or parallel was found. This is one of them.

Kokkinos, Herodian Dynasty, 165, claims that this is a Greek name, but I doubt it. It is perhaps an Idumean name (Oren & Rappaport, IEJ 34 [1984] 146). פרירא/פרידא means “pebble” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1225, 1228). פירורא means “mush, crumble” in Aramaic (Jastrow, ibid. 1171).

פרח means “flower” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1223-4). This name is not biblical, although it is Hebrew and built in the biblical theophoric tradition. אפרח as a name is recorded often on First Temple Hebrew seals (CWSSS nos. 88, 426, 450-4). Zunz, Namen, 7, views this as an innovative Hebrew name of the Second Temple period.
פרת refers to the “River Euphratus” (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1244). The form FRT is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 464).

צבו means “will, desire, wilingness” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1257). The name צובו is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 994. The form ṢB is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 365).
The forms ṢDQ’L/ṢDQ’LY are recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 369).
צום means “fast” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1267-8). The form ṢMY is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 376) and in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 48).
צרדא is a name of a bird in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1299). The form ṢRD is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 371).
For some names no etymology or parallel was found. This is one of them.
קדומא means “east wind” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1313). The name קדמו is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 1008. The form QDMN is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 478).
The name קוזא, קיזא, קיזו and קייזו are recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, nos. 1010, 1019, 1020, 1021.
קוי means “to care, to heap up” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1326). The form QWY is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 491).
The form QNY is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 490).
The form QWQWN is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 491). The form QWQH is recorded for Palmyrenes (Stark, PNPI, 48).
קורא means “partridge” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1341).
The name קוסיהב is recorded for Edomeans (AOFCI132, 134). The form QŠBT is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 482).

קיום means “preservation, storage” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1356). The name קיומא is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 1018. The form QYM is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 492). The form QYMY is recorded for Palmyrens (Stark, PNPI, 48).
In vol. 4 (pp. 294-5), this name is recorded under Arabic Names. The form ̣QYS is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 492). The form QYS’ is recorded for Palmyrans (Stark, PNPI, 48).
קיפא means “coagulation, jelly sediments of boiled meat” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1365). קיפו is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 1030).
קפרס means “caper-bush (κάππαρις)”(Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1403). QPR is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 485).
קצצתא means “timber, cut board, plank” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1408).
קצרא means “fuller, washer” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1408). The form Q̣SR is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 482).
The form QR‘ is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 480).
קרחה/קרחא means “ice” or “weaver” or “baldness” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1415). QRḤ is a biblical name (e.g. Num 16:1). It is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 479).
ראשון means “first” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1437). The form RŠN is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 278).
רדיפה means “pursuing” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYYML, 1452). The name רדיפא is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 1058. The form RDF is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 275).
רטיב means “moist, succulent, fresh” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1471).

ריש/רישא means “head” or alternatively “poison” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1477-8). RŠ’Y, is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 278). The Nabatean רישו is also recorded (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 1071).
The form Š’B is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 336).
Names with the element Šahen are common in Iranian, see Justi, INB, 275. This form is not recorded.
שונם is the name of a biblical city, see e.g. Josh 19:18.
For some names no etymology or parallel was found. This is one of them.
This name is documented on Hebrew seals from the First Temple period, see CWSSS no. 280 (and perhaps also no. 588).
שקל is the name of a coin in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1623). The form ŠQLT is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 353).
שכחה means “forgetfullness” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1572). The name שכוחו is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 1127.
שלק means “seathing over-boiled” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1588).
שמחה means “joy, rejoicing, festive occaison” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1593).
שמלה means “garment” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1596).
The form ŠMR is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 357).
שקפא means “cleft, overhanging rock” or “lintel, threshold,” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1625).
The form ŠRY is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 346). Many Persian names include the prefix Šahr. On the name Šahran see Justi, INB, 276.
שרף means “angel” in Hebrew, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1633. The name שרפיו is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, 1191. The form SRF is recorded for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 316.
ששון in Hebrew means “happiness,” see Jer 7:24.
The form ŠŠ‘’ is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 348).
The form THM is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 140).

תומא means “simplicity” or “garlic” or “fringe” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1654). T’M is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 127). The Nabatean name תאומא is recorded (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 1193).
This name derives from the Hebrew root חלף (exchange).
תמוז is the name of the fourth month and is the name of a Babylonian deity (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1676).
תמלי means “yesterday” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1677). The name תמלת is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 1235. The form TML is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 137).

תנחומין means “consolation” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1681). The name תנחם is documented in Hebrew and Ammonite First Temple seals (CWSSS nos. 707-8, 947). The Greek Θανοῦμας is recorded twice on clearly Christian inscriptions from Sinai, see A. Negev, The Inscriptions of Wadi Haggag, Sinai (Qedem6; Jerusalem 1977) Inscriptions 26 and 75.
For some names no etymology or parallel was found. This is one of them.
The form TRYM is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 132).
